_header: Some time this world was so steadfast and stable
Note:
See 3563 for stanzas incorporated into another poem; editions which do not specify source include Urry (1721)
XUrry, John. The Works of Geoffrey Chaucer. London: B. Lintot, 1721, 547; Chalmers (1810)
XChalmers, Alexander. The Works of the English Poets from Chaucer to Cowper. London, 1810; repr. New York: Greenwood, 1969, 1.553-54; Clarke (1835)
XClarke, Charles Cauder. The Riches of Chaucer. London: T. Tegg, 1835, 1839, 2.304.
Subjects: envoys; mutability; friends, false; transitoriness, of world; evils of the time; advice, to princes; princes, advice to
_description: Geoffrey Chaucer, ‘Lak of Stedfastnesse’ — four stanzas rhyme royal, including one-stanza Envoy

BodFair16.First Lines:
Some tyme the worlde was so stedfast and stableThat mannes worde
                    was obligacioun…
BodFair16.Last Lines:
…Drede god do law loue trouthe and worthynesseAnd wedde thy
                    folke ayeyne to stedfastnesse
BodFair16.Facsimiles:
Norton-Smith,  John. 
             “Introduction.” 
             Bodleian Library MS Fairfax 16.
         London: Scolar Press, 1979.
BodFair16.Editions:
Furnivall,  Frederick James,
                        ed.  
             A Parallel-Text Edition of Chaucer’s Minor Poems.
             3 vols. 
             Chaucer Society
         1st. ser. 21, 57, 58. London: Trübner, n.d. repr. New York and
            London: Johnson, 1967.

BodHat73.First Lines:
Sumtyme this world was so stedefast and stablethat mannes word was
                    obligacioun…
BodHat73.Last Lines:
…Drede god do lawe loue trouthe & rightwesnesseAnd dryue
                    thi peple a gayn to stedefastnesse
BodHat73.Attributed Title:
These baladdis were send to the kyng (f. 119); Lenvoy (in the right margin
                    against the last stanza)
BodHat73.Editions:
Furnivall,  Frederick James,

             Odd Texts of the Minor Poems.
             2 vols. 
             Chaucer Society
         1st ser. 23, 60. London: Trübner, 1868, 1880; repr. New York and
            London: Johnson, 1967.

CamMagPep2553.First Lines:
Sum tyme þe warld so stedfast wes and stableThat manis word
                    wes obligatioun…
CamMagPep2553.Last Lines:
…Dreid god do law luf treuth and rychtuousnesAnd leid þi
                    folk agane to stedfastnes

CamTCC600.First Lines:
Sume tyme þis worlde was so stedfast and stableÞat mans
                    worde was holde for obligacyone…
CamTCC600.Last Lines:
…Dreede god do lawe love trouth and worþynesseAnd dryve
                    þy people ageine to stidfastnesse
CamTCC600.Attributed Title:
Balade Royal made by oure laureal poete of Albyoun in hees laste yeeres (p.
                    356); Balades by Chaucer Made (RT)
CamTCC600.Editions:

A Variorum Edition of The Works of Geoffrey Chaucer

BLHar7333.First Lines:
SVme tyme this worlde was so stedfaste & stableThat manis owrde
                    was holde obligacioun…
BLHar7333.Last Lines:
…Drede god do lawe love thorow all goddnesseAnd drive thi
                    peple A geyne to stedfastnesse
BLHar7333.Attributed Title:
This balade made Geffrey Caunciers the / Laureall Poete Of albioun and sent
                    it to / his souerain lorde kynge Richarde the secounde þane being in his
                    Castell of Windesore (f. 147va, rubric)
BLHar7333.Editions:
Furnivall,  Frederick James,
                        ed.  
             A One-Text Print of the Minor Poems.
         2 pts. London: Trübner, 1871, 1880; repr. New York and London:
            Johnson, 1967.

BLHar7578.First Lines:
Somme tyme worlde was stedfast and stableThat manys worde was
                    obligacion…
BLHar7578.Last Lines:
…dreed god doo lawe loue trouth and worthinesseAnd weed thine
                    folke agayne to stedfastnesse
BLHar7578.Note:

                    Henry IV’ (f. 17v).

CovAcc3251.First Lines:
SOme time þe world was so stedfast & stableThat mannes
                    worde was obligacioun…
CovAcc3251.Last Lines:
…ffro Righte to wronge for trouth to fekilnesseThat all is
                    lost for defaute of stedefastnesse

Banna.First Lines:

                    folk agane to steidfastnes

TCD432.First Lines:
…[ ]es that desyre to be honerable[ ]isshe þe youre folk
                    hate extorciounSuffer no thing þat may be
                    reprouable…
TCD432.Last Lines:
…What causeþ this but sotel dowblenesÞat is lost for
                    lak of stedfastnes
